pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the Bhagga country at Susumāragira in the Bhesakaḷā Grove, the deer park.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.1.2: On one occason during winter the monks were warming themselves after setting fire to a hollow log.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.1.3: Being heated by the fire, a black snake came out of the log and attacked the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.1.4: The monks ran here and there.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.1.5: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.1.7: “How can those monks light a fire to warm themselves?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.1.8: “Is it true, monks, that some monks did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.1.11: How can those foolish men light a fire to warm themselves?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.1.12: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.1.13: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.1.14: ‘If a monk lights a fire to warm himself, or gets one lit, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.1.15: In this way the Master laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.2.1: At one time a number of monks were sick.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.2.2: The monks who were looking after them asked,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.2.3: “We hope you’re bearing up; we hope you’re getting better?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.2.4: “Previously we lit a fire to warm ourselves,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.2.6: But now that this has been prohibited by the Master, we don’t warm ourselves because we’re afraid of wrongdoing. Because of that we’re not comfortable.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.2.8: “Monks, I allow a sick monk to light a fire to warm himself, or to get one lit.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.2.9: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.2.10: ‘If a monk who is not sick lights a fire to warm himself, or gets one lit, he commits an offense entailing confession.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:1.2.11: In this way the Master laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:2.1.1: Soon afterwards the monks did not light lamps, small fires, or saunas because they were afraid of wrongdoing.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:2.1.3: “Monks, I allow you to light a fire, or to get one lit, if there’s a suitable reason.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:2.1.4: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:2.1.5: ‘If a monk who is not sick lights a fire to warm himself, or gets one lit, unless there is an appropriate reason, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.1.4: …The monk who has been given the full ordination by a complete Order through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.1.7: he is comfortable without a fire.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.1.9: he is not comfortable without a fire.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.1.15: if he lights it himself, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.1.17: if he asks another, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.1.18: If he only asks once, then even if the other lights many fires, he commits one offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.1.19: Unless there is a appropriate reason:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.1.20: except if there is an appropriate reason.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.2.1: If he is not sick, and he does not perceive himself as sick, and he lights a fire to warm himself, or gets one lit, unless there is an appropriate reason, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.2.2: If he is not sick, but he is unsure of it, and he lights a fire to warm himself, or gets one lit, unless there is an appropriate reason, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.2.3: If he is not sick, but he perceives himself as sick, and he lights a fire to warm himself, or gets one lit, unless there is an appropriate reason, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.2.4: If he puts back a burning piece of wood that has fallen off, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.2.5: If he is sick, but he does not perceive himself as sick, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.2.6: If he is sick, but he is unsure if he is, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.2.7: If he is sick, and he perceives himself as sick, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.3.2: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc56:3.3.3: The sixth rule, the training rule on fire, is finished.
